sentences.sentence: It was nearly two o’clock when we reached Mrs. Cecil Forrester’s.
The servants had gone to bed hours ago, but Mrs. Forrester had been so interested by the strange message which Miss Morstan had received that she had sat up in the hope of( 期待着 ) her return.

She opened the door herself, a middle-aged, graceful( 优雅的 ) woman, and it gave me joy to see how tenderly her arm wrapped( 围住 ) round the other’s waist, and how motherly was the voice in which she greeted her.
Miss Morstan was clearly no mere employee, but an honored friend.
I was introduced, and Mrs. Forrester earnestly asked me to come in and tell her our adventures.
I explained, however, the importance of my task, and promised faithfully to call and report any progress which we might make with the case.

As we drove away I looked back, and I still seemed to see that little group on the step, the two graceful( 优雅的 ), clinging( 抱紧 ) figures, the half-opened door, and the hall light shining through stained glass.
It was soothing( 使人宽慰的 ) to catch even that passing glimpse of( 瞥一眼 ) a peaceful English home in the midst( 中间 ) of the wild, dark business which had overtaken( 突然降临于 ) us.
And the more I thought of what had happened, the wilder and darker it grew.
I reviewed the whole extraordinary sequence( 一连串 ) of events as I rattled( （车辆）哐啷哐啷前进 ) on through the silent streets.
There was the original problem: that at least was pretty clear now.
The death of Captain Morstan, the sending of the pearls( 珍珠 ), the advertisement( 启事 ), the letter—we understood all those events.
They had only led us, however, to a deeper and far more tragic( 悲剧的 ) mystery( 神秘事件 ).
The Indian treasure, the strange map found among Morstan’s baggage,
the strange scene at Major Sholto’s death, the rediscovery of the treasure immediately followed by the murder of the discoverer,
the very unusual circumstances of the crime, the footsteps, the remarkable weapons( 武器 ), the words upon the card, corresponding( 符合的，相关的 ) with those upon Captain Morstan’s chart—
here was indeed a maze( 纷繁复杂的情节 ) in which a man less specially gifted than my fellow lodger( 房客 ) might well despair( 感到无望 ) of ever finding the clue( 线索 ).
Pinchin Lane was a row of shabby two-storied brick houses.
I had to knock for some time at No. 3 before I got any response.
At last, however, there was the light of a candle behind the curtain, and a face looked out at the upper window.
“Go away,” said a voice from above, “if you make any more noise, I’ll let out forty-three dogs upon you.”
“If you’ll let one out, it’s just what I have come for,” said I.
“Go away!” yelled the voice.
“Mr. Sherlock Holmes—” I began, and the words had a most magical effect, for within a minute the door was unbarred and opened by a tall, thin old man.
“A friend of Mr. Sherlock is always welcome,” said he. “Don’t worry about the snake, sir; it’s not poisonous, and I leave it out to eat the beetles( 甲壳虫 ).
I hope you don’t mind my being rude to you at first. What was it that Mr. Sherlock Holmes wanted, sir?”
“He wanted a dog of yours.”
“Ah! That would be Toby.”
“Yes, Toby was the name.”
“Toby lives at No. 7 on the left here.”
I could see that he kept many animals of different kinds.
Even the ceiling above our heads was lined with cages full of birds, who lazily shifted their weight from one leg to the other as our voices disturbed their sleep.
Toby proved to be an ugly, long-haired, long-eared creature, brown and white in color, with a slow, clumsy walk.

It accepted after some hesitation( 犹豫 ) a lump( 块 ) of sugar which the old naturalist handed to me, and, having thus sealed an alliance( 结盟 ), it followed me to the cab, and made no objection to accompanying me.
The Palace clock had just struck three when I found myself back once more at Pondicherry Lodge.
The ex-prize-fighter( 前职业拳击手 ) McMurdo had, I found, been arrested as an accessory( 同谋 ), and both he and Mr. Sholto had been marched off to the station.
Two policemen guarded the narrow gate, but they allowed me to pass with the dog on my mentioning the detective’s name.
Holmes was standing on the doorstep, with his hands in his pockets, smoking his pipe.
“Ah, you have him there!” said he. “Good dog, then! Athelney Jones has gone. We have had an immense( 巨大的 ) display( 展现 ) of energy since you left.
He has arrested not only friend Thaddeus, but the gatekeeper, the housekeeper, and the Indian servant.
We have the place to ourselves, except for a sergeant( 巡佐 ) upstairs.
Leave the dog here, and come up.”
We tied Toby to the hall table, and climbed back up the stairs.
The room was as we had left it, except that a sheet had been placed over the central figure.
A tired-looking police-sergeant( 巡佐 ) was resting in the corner.
“I must kick off( 踢开 ) my boots and stockings( 长袜 ),” said my companion. “Please carry them down with you, Watson.
I am going to do a little climbing. And dip my handkerchief into the tar( 焦油 ).
That will do. Now come up into the attic( 阁楼 ) with me for a moment.”
We climbed up through the hole.
Holmes turned his light once more upon the footsteps in the dust.
“Take a look at these footmarks,” he said. “Do you observe anything noteworthy( 值得注意的 ) about them?”
“They belong,” I said, “to a child or a small woman.”
“Apart from their size, though. Is there nothing else?”
“They appear to be much as other footmarks.”
“Not at all. Look here! This is the print of a right foot in the dust. Now I make one with my naked( 赤裸的 ) foot beside it. What’s the main difference?”
“Your toes( 脚趾 ) are all squeezed together. The other print has each toe( 脚趾 ) distinctly divided.”
“Quite so. That is the point. Bear that in mind. Now, would you kindly step over to the trap door( 通气门 ) and smell the edge of the woodwork?
I shall stay here, as I have this handkerchief in my hand.”
I did as he directed, and was instantly conscious of a strong tarry( 沾了焦油的 ) smell.
“That is where he put his foot in getting out. If you can trace( 发现 ) him, I should think that Toby will have no difficulty.
Now run downstairs, release( 释放 ) the dog, and try to find our climber.”

article_info.previous: 警探完成了自己的推理并宣布逮捕Thaddeus，而Holmes则指出真正的凶手还在逍遥法外，甚至描绘出了其中一位凶手Jonathan Small。事情告一段落后Watson护送Miss Morstan回家，在路上他又一次陷入了激烈的心理斗争。
article_info.share_words: As we drove away I looked back, and I still seemed to see that little group on the step, the two graceful, clinging figures, the half-opened door, and the hall light shining through stained glass.

question.cn: Mrs. Cecil Forrester对Miss Morstan怎样呢？
question.en: How did Mrs. Cecil Forrester treat Miss Morstan?

options.cn: 夫人把Miss Morstan仅仅看作雇员并且对她很差。
options.en: She saw Miss Morstan just as an employee and treated her badly.

options.cn: 夫人把Miss Morstan看作朋友一样，很关心她。
options.en: She saw Miss Morstan as a friend and cared about her.

options.cn: 夫人对Miss Morstan总是很冷漠。
options.en: She always treated Miss Morstan with great indifference.

analysis: 文中提到：“. . . and it gave me joy to see how tenderly her arm wrapped round the other’s waist, and how motherly was the voice in which she greeted her. Miss Morstan was clearly no mere employee, but an honored friend. ”因此答案选B。

question.cn: Watson对这桩案件的看法是怎样？
question.en: What did Watson think of the case?

options.cn: 他认为在如此复杂的情况下很难找出线索。
options.en: He thought it difficult to find the clue under such complex situation.

options.cn: 他认为这桩案件很常见。
options.en: He thought the case was just commonplace.

options.cn: 他认为所有人都可以轻易地解决这个问题。
options.en: He thought everyone could solve the problem easily.

analysis: 文中Watson在回忆整桩案件之后得出结论：“. . . here was indeed a maze in which a man less specially gifted than my fellow lodger might well despair of ever finding the clue.”因此答案选A。

question.cn: 下列有关那个住在Pinchin Lane第3号的男人的说法，哪一个是正确的？
question.en: Which of the following statements about the man at No.3 Pinchin Lane is CORRECT?

options.cn: 他一直都很亲切和温柔。
options.en: He was kind and gentle all the time.

analysis: 文中一开始这个男人的态度是比较粗鲁的，但听到是Sherlock Holmes有求后态度发生了巨大转变，说道：“I hope you don’t mind my being rude to you at first. What was it that Mr. Sherlock Holmes wanted, sir?”后文Watson注意到：“I could see that he kept many animals of different kinds. ”因此答案选B。

question.cn: Watson离开Pondicherry Lodge之后发生了什么？
question.en: What happened after Watson had left Pondicherry Lodge?

options.cn: Mr.Athelney逮捕了看门人、管家和印度仆人。
options.en: Mr.Athelney arrested the gatekeeper, the housekeeper and the Indian servant.

options.cn: Holmes找出了罪犯的所在之处。
options.en: Holmes worked out of where the criminal was.

options.cn: Mr.Athelney没有再逮捕其他人，并离开了Pondicherry Lodge。
options.en: Mr. Athelney arrested no one else and left Pondicherry Lodge.

analysis: 文中提到：“Athelney Jones has gone. We have had an immense display of energy since you left. He has arrested not only friend Thaddeus, but the gatekeeper, the housekeeper, and the Indian servant. ”因此答案选A。

question.cn: 除了大小，这些脚印还有什么值得注意的地方？
question.en: What was worth noting about the footmarks apart from their size?

options.cn: 跟Holmes的脚一样，所有脚趾都挤在一起。
options.en: All toes were squeezed together like that of Holmes’s.

options.cn: 它们的数量跟其它脚印差不多。
options.en: They appear to be much as other footmarks.

analysis: 文中提到：“Your toes are all squeezed together. The other print has each toe distinctly divided.”因此答案选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第32天
